name: hydrogen sulfide production | hydrogen sulfide | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/1675/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of gaseous hydrogen sulfide, obtained by processing molten sulfur recovered from refinery gases. Hydrogen sulfide (H2S) is a colourless, but smelling (rotten-egg odour) gas that is heavier than air. Hydrogen sulfide that is recovered from natural gas or refinery gases is mostly converted into sulfur. Other applications include the use of H2S in the production of metal sulfides, purification of ores by flotation processes and catalyst activation.;The inventory is based on literature data and estimations.;References:;Hischier R., Classen M., Lehmann M. and Scharnhorst W. (2007) Life cycle inventories of Electric and Electronic Equipment: Production, Use and Disposal. ecoinvent report No. 18. Empa / Technology & Society Lab, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, 2007.;Pouliquen, F., Blanc, C., Arretz, E., Labat, I., Tournier-Lasserve, J., Ladousse, A., Nougayrede, J., Savin, G., Ivaldi, R., Nicolas, M., Fialaire, J., Millischer, R., Azema, C., Espagno, L., Hemmer, H. and Perrot, J. 2000. Hydrogen Sulfide. Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry.;Unitel Technologies (2015) Hydrogen Sulfide (H2S) Production Technology, http://www.uniteltech.com/tech-library (accessed on 2017-08-10).

From reception of raw materials at the factory gate.

This activity ends with the production of hydrogen sulfide. The dataset includes the consumption of raw materials and chemicals used for production, as well as the energy use and infrastructure use of the plant. Solid wastes and emissions to air and water are omitted.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The time period is based on the dates of the literature sources.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Data used has no specific geographical origin.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Hydrogen sulfide can be either produced by a chemical reaction – e.g. between sulfur and hydrogen, sulfur and hydrocarbons or sulfides and dilute acid – but it can also be recovered from natural gas or refinery gases. This inventory models the use of sulfur recovered from refinery gases, which is melted and then processed into hydrogen sufide.;Reference:;Hischier R., Classen M., Lehmann M. and Scharnhorst W. (2007) Life cycle inventories of Electric and Electronic Equipment: Production, Use and Disposal. ecoinvent report No. 18. Empa / Technology & Society Lab, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, 2007.;Pouliquen, F., Blanc, C., Arretz, E., Labat, I., Tournier-Lasserve, J., Ladousse, A., Nougayrede, J., Savin, G., Ivaldi, R., Nicolas, M., Fialaire, J., Millischer, R., Azema, C., Espagno, L., Hemmer, H. and Perrot, J. 2000. Hydrogen Sulfide. Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: The data is based on literature.

exchanges.description:
Hydrogen sulfide, also called monosulfane, is a colourless, but smelling (rotten-egg odour) gas that is heavier than air. Hydrogen sulfide occurs naturally in a variety of systems - resulting in natural releases in the order of 1 to 3x108 tonnes, originating from e.g. oceans (about 50% of releases), volcanos, flooded grounds and further hydrogeological sources. In addition this substance can be found in natural gas, for which hydrogen sulfide has been regarded until the late 1950s as a toxic, corrosive component that has to be eliminated.
The most important use of hydrogen sulfide is in the production of sulphur – especially from the one recovered from natural gas. Furthermore it can be used for the production of metal sulfides, purification of ores by flotation processes or for catalyst activation.

flow.name: hydrogen sulfide
flow.category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

exchanges.description:
Literature value. Approximately 150 kg of steam (at 4 bar) is consumed to produce 1 tonne of H2S (Unitel Technologies 2015). It is assumed that the energy content of steam is 2.75 MJ/kg (Althaus et al. 2007).

Reference:
Unitel Technologies (2015) Hydrogen Sulfide (H2S) Production Technology, http://www.uniteltech.com/tech-library (accessed on 2017-08-10).
Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.

exchanges.description:
Calculated based on literature data published by the industry. For this activity, no information was readily available concerning infrastructure and land-use. Therefore, the infrastructure is estimated based on data from two chemical factories, the BASF site of Ludwigshafen and the chemical factory in Gendorf (which are both located in Germany), which produce a wide range of chemical substances. Based on this data, the following assumptions are made: the built area amounts to about 4.2 ha, the plant has an average output of 50'000 t/a and a lifespan of fifty years. The estimated infrastructure amount is therefore 4.00 E-10 units per kg of produced chemical.

References:
Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.
Gendorf (2000) Umwelterklärung 2000, Werk Gendorf. Werk Gendorf, Burgkirchen.

exchanges.description: Calculated as a fraction of the input of water. For more details, refer to the mathematical relation and the parameters.

Literature value. 1066 kg of molten sulfur (99% purity) is required to produce 1 tonne of H2S (95% purity) (Pouliquen et al. 2000).

Reference:
Pouliquen, F., Blanc, C., Arretz, E., Labat, I., Tournier-Lasserve, J., Ladousse, A., Nougayrede, J., Savin, G., Ivaldi, R., Nicolas, M., Fialaire, J., Millischer, R., Azema, C., Espagno, L., Hemmer, H. and Perrot, J. 2000. Hydrogen Sulfide. Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry.

Reference:

exchanges.description: Calculated as a fraction of the input of water. For more details, refer to the mathematical relation and the parameters.

Approximately 70 BTU of heat is required to convert one pound of solid sulfur at about 60°F (16°C) to one kg of liquid sulfur at about 280°F (138°C).

Reference:
sulphuric-acid.com (2010), Sulphur Systems - Sulphur Melting, http://sulphuric-acid.com/TechManual/Sulphur/melting.htm (accessed on the 2017-08-09).
